This file defines constants and data types used by system calls.

#define SYSCALL_ALLOCATE   (8)

System call that allocates a memory block.

The length of the requested memory block is passed in rdi. Allocation flags for the block is passed in rsi. The system call returns the address or an error code.

Definition at line 55 of file sysdefines.h.

Referenced by alloc().

#define SYSCALL_ALLOCATEPORT   (10)

System call that allocates a port.

The identity number of the port is passed in rdi. The system call returns a handle to the port or an error code if unsuccessful.

Definition at line 73 of file sysdefines.h.

Referenced by allocateport().

#define SYSCALL_CREATEPROCESS   (5)

System call that creates a new process with one single thread.

It takes an index into the executable table in rdi. The program used is the executable whose index is passed in rdi.

Definition at line 40 of file sysdefines.h.

Referenced by createprocess().

#define SYSCALL_DEBUGGER   (3)

System call that pauses execution by invoking the bochs debugger.

Definition at line 28 of file sysdefines.h.

Referenced by debugger().

#define SYSCALL_FINDPORT   (11)

System call that finds a port.

The identity number of the port is passed in rdi. The owning process identity is passed in rsi. The system call returns a handle to the port or an error code if unsuccessful.

Definition at line 79 of file sysdefines.h.

Referenced by findport().

#define SYSCALL_FREE   (9)

System call that frees a memory block allocated through the allocate system call.

The address of the memory block is passed in rdi. The system call returns ALL_OK if successful or an error code if unsuccessful.

#define SYSCALL_PAUSE   (6)

System call that blocks the calling thread a number of clocks ticks.

The number of clock ticks is passed in rdi. There are 200 clock ticks per second.

Definition at line 24 of file sysdefines.h.

#define SYSCALL_RECEIVE   (14)

System call that receives a message.

The handle of the port on which to receive is passed in rdi. 1 is passed in register rsi if long messages are permitted. Register rbx holds a pointer to a buffer that will hold the received message.

The system call returns ALL_OK if successful or an error code if unsuccessful. Register rsi holds the received message type. Register rdi holds the identity of process from which the message was received.

NOTE: You only need to implement short messages functionality in task 5B. Notification and long messages functionality is implemented in task 5A. The functionality to be implemented in task 5A has a slightly different interface. This interface is described in the instructions.

Definition at line 116 of file sysdefines.h.

Referenced by receive(), and receive_long().

#define SYSCALL_SEND   (12)

System call that sends a message.

The handle of the destination port is passed in rdi. The message type is passed in rsi. A pointer to the message is passed in rbx. The system call returns ALL_OK if successful or an error code if unsuccessful.

There are three defined message types: short messages, long messages and notifications. Short messages are passed in registers. Notifications are single bit messages that will never block. Long messages are partially located in memory.

NOTE: You only need to implement short messages functionality in task 5B. Notification and long messages functionality is implemented in task 5A. The functionality to be implemented in task 5A has a slightly different interface. This interface is described in the instructions.

Definition at line 96 of file sysdefines.h.

Referenced by send(), send_long(), and send_notification().

#define SYSCALL_TERMINATE   (4)

System call that terminates the currently running thread.

It takes no parameters. Terminates the process when there are no threads left.

Definition at line 34 of file sysdefines.h.

Referenced by terminate().

#define SYSCALL_TIME   (7)

System call that returns the current system time.

The system time is the number of clock ticks since system start. There are 200 clock ticks per second.

Definition at line 50 of file sysdefines.h.

Referenced by time().

#define SYSCALL_VERSION   (0)

System call that returns the version of the kernel.
